Your 401(k) Plan  
Essentials 
 
 
In fact, your 401(k) plan can offer tax-deferred savings, compounding growth, and the ease of saving through 
payroll deductions. Review this plan information to see how the plan can help you save, invest and prepare for 
retirement. This overview is not intended as a comprehensive explanation. For more detailed plan information, 
refer to the plan’s Summary Plan Description (SPD) or the Plan Document.  
 
 
ELIGIBILITY  
Generally, all non-union employees who are at least 21 years old and have completed 3 months of service may 
participate in the plan. 
 
ENROLLMENT 
To participate, you need to enroll and select your contribution rate 
and investment elections. Before you are fully eligible to participate, 
you can enroll during the pre-eligibility period. Contributions will begin 
generally within 1-2 payroll periods after you are eligible.   
 
GET STARTED WITH YOUR 401(K)  
You'll find a number of resources online to help you get enrolled and 
manage your 401(k) account. Account FAQs  
 
• Log in to the Insperity Premier portal at portal.insperity.com  and click on the 401(k) link. 
• Select the 'Enroll Now' button to access the Retirement Service CenterSM. 
• Use the SmartPlan tool for help in getting enrolled or use the Quick Enroll wizard to enter your 
contribution rate (pre-tax and Roth) and investment elections. 
• Once your enrollment has been processed, you'll be able to to access your account at any time to 
make changes.  
Have questions about 
enrolling? 
 
Look for the enrollment 
video in the  
401(k) Toolbox 

 
 5257100     105001 - 113209 
   20398 (45776)  Questions? Call the Insperity Contact Center at 866.715.3552, option 3. Hablamos español. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
CONTRIBUTIONS 
Your Employee Contributions  
You may make pre-tax and/or Roth after-tax contributions of 1% to 80% (in 1% increments) of your  eligible 
compensation per pay period, including wages, overtime, bonuses, and  commissions. You may change or stop 
your payroll contributions anytime, which will generally take effect within 1 -2 payroll periods. 
 
There is a limit on how much you can contribute to your 401(k) account each year. If you are age 50 or older, the 
annual limit includes catch-up contributions. The annual limits apply only to what you contribute from your 
paychecks; employer contributions are not included. 
 
Check Annual Limits for the current limits set by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).  
 
For participants who are considered "highly compensated employees," as defined by the Internal Revenue Code 
(IRC), employee elective deferrals may be further limited by annual nondiscrimination test ing.  
 
Employer Contributions 
The plan provides an employer matching contribution in an amount equal to  100% of your contributions on the 
first 4% of your eligible compensation made each payroll period.  You are always 100% vested in all plan 
contributions plus any earnings so you immediately own the money deposited into your account.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Rollover Contributions 
You may make rollover contributions from a prior employers’ tax -qualified plans and certain annuity contracts and 
IRAs. Call the Contact Center for details or review the Rollover FAQs. 
Don’t miss out! When you contribute  4% of your paycheck, you will get an 
additional 4% added to your 401(k) account. 
 
To maximize the amount of match received annually, contribute continuously 
throughout the year.  
 
 
 
 
 
 5257100     105001 - 113209 
   20398 (45776)  Questions? Call the Insperity Contact Center at 866.715.3552, option 3. Hablamos español. 
KEY THINGS TO KEEP IN MIND 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
INVESTMENT OPTIONS 
The plan offers a variety of investments to choose from and you may make changes to your investments by accessing 
your account. For a full list of the investment options available to you, check the Investment Summary.  
 
The series of target-date retirement funds are the qualified default 
investment alternative funds under the plan. You have the option to 
choose a target retirement fund based on your anticipated retirement 
date or create your portfolio from the investments available under the 
plan.  
 
LOANS 
The plan allows you to take a loan from your account in accordance with the plan’s loan policy. The loan, 
including interest, is repaid to your 401(k) account through payroll deductions . Loan FAQs 
• Borrow minimum of $1,000 up to a maximum of $50,000 (reduced by your highest outstanding loan 
balance during the prior 12 months), as long as it is no more than 50% of your vested account balance  
• Interest equals the Prime Rate as published in The Wall Street Journal + 1% (fixed rate for the term of the loan) 
 
WITHDRAWALS AND DISTRIBUTIONS 
You may withdraw money from your 401(k) account under the following circumstances: 
• You may take an in-service distribution after reaching age 59½ or request a withdrawal before then for certain 
financial hardships 
• Any rollover balance you have may be withdrawn at any time 
• Generally, 25 days after your termination of employment, you may take  a distribution 
 
Some withdrawals and distributions may be subject to a 10% early withdrawal penalty and mandatory 
income tax withholding. You may want to talk with your tax advisor before withdrawing any money from 
your plan account. For more information, review these Withdrawals and Distributions FAQs.

PARTICIPANT FEES 
• $3.60 will be deducted from your account each month to cover administrative expenses  
This amount may be adjusted periodically 
• Investment fund expense ratios vary - refer to the fund’s documents for detailed fee information 
• $12.50 quarterly maintenance fee per loan  
• $50.00 processing fee per withdrawal or distribution from your account 
• Additional fees apply for certain participant requested transactions, including reissued checks 
 
LOOKING FOR MORE? 
 
• 401(k) Toolbox is an educational guide to empower you with knowledge and tools at every stage of your 
401(k) journey. It’s packed with valuable tips, detailed guides, and answers to your most -asked questions. 
 
• Planning Calculators are available to help you decide how much to contribute, whether you are on track, 
withdrawal strategies, and much more. 
 
• Morningstar® Retirement Managersm provides tailored advice and investment management to help you 
reach your retirement goals. For more information about specific services or to schedule a 1:1 
consultation, call the Morningstar team at 877-525-3271. 
 
For assistance with your account, contact the Insperity Contact Center at 866 -715-3552, option 3, or 
by email at contact_center@insperity.com. Specialists are available Monday through Friday, 7 a.m. – 
7 p.m. CT.

Flexible Spending Account  Plan
Available to   full-time employees  who work 30+ hours per week (20+ hours  in  Hawaii) on  a verage
When 
you  enroll  in  the Insperity Health  Ca re Flexible Spending Account  Plan (Health  Care FSA),  you  can  make pretax
contributions up to the annual maximum through payroll deduction and use those contributions to pay for qualifying
health  care expenses incurred  during  the calendar year.
You  may elect  to  contribute up to  the annual  maximum set by the IRS each  year.
Please note that the annual  limit  will  be prorated  based on the number  of remaining  pay periods  in  the calendar year
at the time your election takes effect.
O
nc
e  enrolled, you  will receive  a  He alth  Car e  Spending  Car d  (a  debit MasterCard® issued by UnitedHealthcare)  funded
with  yo ur  ele cted amount.  Us e the card for eligible expenses at the time of service,  or  ﬁle a  claim  for  rei mbursement.
Eligible expenses  inc lude copays,  coi nsurance, and  deductibles for  me dical,  prescription,  dental  and   vision  expenses,
as  well  as  certain over-the-counter health care expenses .  See IRS Publication  5 02 for  a  cu rrent  list  of
qualiﬁed  expenses.
You  can  ﬁle claims  for any eligible expenses incurred during the plan year through  Ma rch  31 of the following year.
Any unused  am ounts are forfeited  under the Plan’s “use it or lose it”  rule.
FSA  C arryover (up to  $500  per y ear)
You  can  carry over up  to $500 of unused contributions if you elect to continue participation  in  the Heal th  Care FSA  for
th
e following plan  yea r.  Any unused amounts  in excess  of $500 will  be forfeited.
For  example,  if you enroll  in  the Health Care FSA  for 2026  and have an unused  bal ance of $700 for  the 2026  plan  year,
you  may carry over  $500  to use for  eligible expenses in  2027  —  but only if you  enroll  in  t he Heal th  Care FSA  for  plan
year  2027.  Th e remaining  $20 0  will  be forfeited  under the plan’s “use it or  lose it” rule.
Tax  considerations
IRS  rules  prohibit individuals with  genera l  purpose health care FSA coverage (including an  eligible spouse and
dep
endents) from contributing to a health savings account (HSA). If you are currently contributing  to an   HSA  (or
intend  to open  and  con tribute to an  HSA), you  s hould not enroll in the Health  Care FSA,  as  participation  will  make you
ineligible to contribute to an HSA  in  t he same calendar year.
Enrollment deadline
Enroll  within  30  days of becoming eligible; no wait period applies. To continue participation  each year,  sub mit a new
election  during  the annual  open  en rollment period.

A) through  the Inspe rity HSA  Pro gram.  Ther e are no federal taxes  on pretax

u  may invest a portion  of your  HSA  balance once it reaches $1,100.  The

Annual  out-of-pocket maximum  (OOPM)
This is the most a participant must  pay out of their own pocket  during the calendar  year   before the plan  begins  to pay
100% of eligible expenses .  Medical  calendar-year  deductibles,  c opays and  coi nsura nce (including  prescriptions,  unless
with  embedded  deductibles  will  have embedded  OOPMs; HDHP coverage options  with aggregate deductibles  will
otherwise noted) generally apply toward satisfying the annual out-of-pocket maximum. Insperity coverage options
have a
ggregate  OOPMs.

is is the amount owed  for certain  co vered health  care services  before t he plan  begins  to pay beneﬁts.  Not all  covered

services require this deductible to be met (e.g., office visit copays under non-HDHP coverage options). All Insperity
coverage options cover in-network physician office visits for preventive care services (as defined in the applicable
Except as otherwise noted  for  certain HDHP-type coverage options, Insperi ty coverage options  generally have
“embedded”  calendar-year  deductibles and  OOP Ms.  For  family coverage under  the embedded  desi gn,  each  covered
th
e individual  member  c an  receive covered  medical  ser vices  or prescri ption  drugs  at c opay or  coinsurance levels.
Ind
ividual  family members are responsible for  their own out-of-pocket covered  medical  exp enses  up to the individual-

family-level  OOP M.
family member needs to satisfy only an individual calendar-year deductible (not the entire family deductible) before

rtain  Ins perity HDHP coverage options have “aggregate” (non-embedded) deductibles and  OOPMs.  For  family
coverage under  the aggrega te design,  the entire f amily calendar-year deductible must  be met  before copays  or
coinsurance will  app ly for any individual  family member. Only after the full  family deductible is  met  will any family
mem
ber  be able to receive covered  medical  services  or  prescripti on  drugs at  cop ay or  coi nsurance levels.  A  family is
responsible for all  its  mem bers’  out-of-pocket  covered me dical expenses   up  to the family-level  OOPM.
Coinsurance
Thi
s is the Plan  or  participant’s share of the cost  of a covered service,  calculated  as a percent of the allowed  amount
for  the service.  Coi nsurance (where appl icable) applies after  the participant  satisﬁes  any applicable calendar-year
deductible.  Als o,  coinsura nce generally will  not apply where a  copay applies.  Unless  otherwise indicated,  percentages
reﬂected  in  the medical  coverage options ch arts  reﬂect the coinsurance amount to be paid  by the participant.

ays

applies, coinsurance will not apply, and you are not required to first satisfy any applicable medical
calendar-year  deductible.
High deductible health  plan  (HDHP) options
HDHP coverage options  generally do not cover any med ical  expenses   other  than  preventive care until  the applicable
calendar-year  deductible is  met .  All  me dical and  pharmacy expenses apply to the applicable calendar-year  deductible
and
  OOPM.  Th ese expenses  are the participant’s  responsibility until  the deductible is  met .  All  Insp erity HDHP

erage options are HSA-qualiﬁed.

Who is CHAMP?
Champ is the leader in building modern solutions for motor vehicle agencies and enterprise businesses nationwide.  Our solutions deliver measurable results at half the cost of legacy providers, reducing processing times from months to less than 24 hours.

Where can I find more information about CHAMP?
Visit - champtitles.com
Visit - LinkedIn
Careers - Open Positions
Media - Press

How long has CHAMP been in business?
Champ was founded in 2018. 
CEO - Shane Bigelow & CTO - Bo Shim

Is Champ a great place to work?
Yes, and some recent testimonials include:
3rd fastest growing company in Cuyahoga County
Top 25 fastest growing companies in Ohio
Best of Small/Medium Tech – Greater Cleveland Partnership 2025
Cleveland.com / Plaindealer – Best Place to Work 2025

Where is Champ located?
Champ is in the West bank of the Flats in Cleveland, OH. 
Address:  2019 Center Street, Floor 2, Cleveland, OH 44113

 We have an onsite culture where employees are onsite 4 days per week.

What does Champ offer employees?
Here are some highlights of what Champ offers the team:

Career Growth – a fast paced, growth-oriented company who is adding to staff
New Office Space – the square footage doubled in the Fall of 2025
Culture – a fun, collaborative team committed to diversity and inclusion.  We recognize the power of different perspectives, backgrounds and skills.  We celebrate these differences and thrive on them for the benefit of our employees, our products and our community








Does Champ offer competitive Compensation & Total Rewards?
Yes, while there are too many comprehensive benefits to list, here are some highlights:

Compensation – highly competitive salaries + bonus opportunities

Benefits – Eligible Day 1 
Medical (variety of options under United Healthcare)
Dental, Vision & Prescription
HSA or LSA
CHAMP contributes $600 annually to all HSAs for Employee Only Coverage
CHAMP contributes $1,200 annually to all HSAs for Spouse, Child, Children, and Family Coverage
401k match - $1 for $1 to 4% and vesting is immediate. (90-day benefit offering)
Perks at Work

Food - snacks, fruit, water, coffee and Energy Drinks provided by the company at no Cost

Harvest Owl – Fresh Meal Delivery Service – CHAMP provides $8.00 reimbursement, up to two meals per week.  ~ $800 year benefit 

Parking - free on street Parking

About the job
At CHAMP, we are redefining the technology used by Motor Vehicle Agencies and their stakeholders. We do so with innovative, cloud-based software that enhances efficiency, security, and interoperability. Our solutions replace outdated processes with modern, scalable platforms, enabling organizations to operate with greater speed and accuracy in an increasingly digital world.



Product Architect

Location: Cleveland (Onsite – 4 days in office)

Department: Product Management

Reports To: Head of Product

Travel: Up to 15%

Sponsorship: This position is not eligible for Visa Sponsorship



Your Impact

We’re looking for a strategic Product Architect to act as the bridge between product, data, and architecture for our complex platforms. This role ensures that business goals and user requirements translate into a scalable, maintainable system with structured, reliable data to support reporting, insights, and seamless integrations, acting as the product steward of our Unified Data Model.

 

 This role is rooted in product discovery and user workflows to ensure new features and configurations align cleanly with our platform model, data standards, and long-term architecture. The ideal candidate thrives at the intersection of product and technology, influencing decisions without formal authority, and enabling teams to deliver high-quality solutions efficiently across complex, multi-layered systems.

 

What You Bring

We welcome candidates from all backgrounds. If you meet most of the qualifications below, we encourage you to apply, even if you don’t meet every single one.



What You’ll Do



Participate in discovery sessions to anticipate technical, data, and platform impacts of new initiatives
Collaborate with product managers and stakeholders to clarify business and user requirements as they relate to data, analytics, and architecture
Help shape the unified data model that balances regulatory requirements, the configurable needs of each state implementation, and the ideal user experience
Ensure the data model supports reliable reporting, insights, and seamless integrations
Communicate decisions and rationale clearly to create share understanding across teams
Serve as a trusted advisor to architecture and engineering teams on how business and user requirements should shape system design, scalability, and data-related impacts
Document decisions, trade-offs, and design patterns to create a shared source of truth for the organization


What We’re Looking For

A strong technical background with experience as a Solution Architect, Software Engineer, Data Engineer, or related role (7+ years)
Proven experience with modern web application frameworks, specifically with React, Angular or Vue, and Java (Spring), PHP, or .NET
Core concepts and practice of MVS, Restful APIs, microservices, and message brokers
Strong understanding of database technologies, both relational (e.g. PostgreSQL, MySQL) and No SQL (e.g. MongoDB, Redis) 
Experience with modern development principles focused on modularity, reusability, scalability, performance, and security best practices
Ability to translate business and user needs into clear technical requirements, data structures, and scalable system designs
Comfortable participating directly with clients in discovery and product conversations, not just implementation
Strong systems thinker who can evaluate tradeoffs, anticipate downstream impacts, and ensure decisions align with the long-term vision of our product portfolio
Collaborative, influence-driven communicator who works well across product, engineering, data, and architecture teams


Why You’ll Like Working Here

Competitive Salary

Annual Bonus Potential

Health, Dental & Vision Insurance

Unlimited PTO Policy

Matching 401K with immediate vesting

Subsidized Lunches at our Cleveland Headquarters

Fast Paced work environment in a growth company

Newly Renovated Office Space



Salary Range

The expected salary range for this position is $140,000 to $175,000 annually. This is a good faith estimate, and final compensation may vary based on experience, skills, and geographic location.



We celebrate diversity and are committed to creating an inclusive environment for all employees. We welcome applicants of all backgrounds, including veterans and individuals with disabilities. If you need accommodations during the application or interview process, please let us know. We’re here to help. 



By joining CHAMP Titles, you will be an integral member of our team with many opportunities for personal growth and upward mobility in a growing organization. We have a great culture that is flexible, collaborative and welcoming.


Benefits found in job post

Vision insurance, 401(k), Medical insurance, Dental insurance

Requirements added by the job poster

• Working in an onsite setting

• Authorized to work in the United States

• No need for visa sponsorship

Summary: 
# Product Discovery and State Implementation Strategy Meeting
Time & Date: Not specified  
Participants: Kevin, Tyler, Abby (referenced), Bo (referenced), Ian (referenced), Britt (referenced), Sarah (referenced), Speaker 3, Speaker 4  
Summary of the Meeting:
- Kevin and Tyler discussed how the team conducts JAD-style discovery sessions for state implementations across multiple DMV-related products, focusing on integration constraints, data model challenges, and a more opinionated product approach to reduce per-state customization.
- They reviewed product lines (Driver IDs, Vehicle Titling and Registration, ELT), inter-state integrations through AAMVA, and in-state integrations (courts, etc.), including the role of state plugins and teams responsible for product vs. implementation.
- They covered the evolution from VTAS V1 to a slimmed Gen 2/headless approach, the need for unified data modeling, and a roadmap for scalable V2 while maintaining system-of-record awareness.
- Organizational roles and hiring were addressed, including a new VP of Engineering (Britt), VP of Product (Abby), VP over state implementations (Ian), enterprise and solution architects, and data team structure changes.
- Logistics and next steps included expected follow-up from Sarah and holiday scheduling notes.
## Topic 1: Nature and Goals of JAD/Product Discovery Sessions
- Kevin explained the purpose: “[Kevin] It’s basically bringing everybody together and getting all the stakeholders in one room.” These sessions trigger conversations among stakeholders who have not previously considered technical constraints and options.
- Tyler aligned with this framing: “[Tyler] … how I refer to it as a product discovery almost.”
- Kevin clarified that while not strictly JAD, the sessions focus on implementation specifics depending on whether the product is new or an existing product entering a new state. The team knows the general product structure and explores “how do we plug” the state’s systems into their product.
- Key constraint discussion example:
  - Unique identifier requirement for titles: “[Kevin] … we really need a unique idea how can we do this …”
  - Some states have mutable identifiers tied to legacy processes: “[Kevin] … developer… well this is how we’ve always done it …”
  - Outcome is to provoke and capture state-side discussions, then have architects propose technical solutions: “[Kevin] … getting those conversations going and then capturing it all and bringing it back. So that then the architects can say, okay, here’s how we can solve this technically.”
- Tyler noted benefit of allowing stakeholders to debate internally: “[Tyler] That’s sometimes, I prefer that sometimes because then I can be a fly on the wall per se.”
Decisions and Direction:
- Use discovery sessions to surface legacy constraints (e.g., lack of unique IDs) and drive toward implementable solutions.
- Capture outcomes for architects to design state-specific integrations.
Challenges:
- Legacy system limitations (e.g., mutable title IDs).
- Cultural resistance to change (“this is how we’ve always done it”).
Planned Actions:
- Continue facilitating stakeholder-led conversations; capture requirements and constraints; feed into architecture.
Action Items for Topic 1:
- Identify Unique Identifier Strategy
  - Description: Document the state’s current title identification scheme and propose a technically feasible unique ID strategy.
  - Responsible: Architects (under Kevin)
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Leverage discovery outputs; consider mapping legacy IDs to stable unique IDs.
- Stakeholder Discovery Facilitation
  - Description: Schedule and run sessions to prompt cross-stakeholder discussion; capture decisions/constraints.
  - Responsible: Abby (business), Solution Architect (to be hired), Kevin’s team
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Maintain comprehensive notes for technical planning.
Open Questions for Topic 1:
- Which states currently have mutable title identifiers and what interim mapping strategies are acceptable to them?
- What specific artifacts are expected post-session for architects (templates, decision logs, integration maps)?
## Topic 2: Scope of JAD/Discovery Across State vs. Dealers and Other Entities
- Tyler asked whether sessions are state-focused or also held with dealerships/smaller entities: “[Tyler] … at the state level or … individual dealerships …”
- Kevin stated it depends, but usually not with smaller entities initially; those may be involved later. For Driver IDs (e.g., Louisiana), focus is almost entirely state-level, with extensive integrations:
  - AAMVA: “[Kevin] … association of motor vehicle administrators … services you have to call … team … working on those updates.”
  - In-state integrations: courts sending DUI records, etc.
- For ELT (Electronic Liens and Titles), primary customers are lenders and their service providers; sessions target service providers for API integrations: “[Kevin] … sessions with them … saying here’s how you call our APIs…”
Decisions and Direction:
- Prioritize state-level JAD for state-centric products (Driver IDs, VTAS).
- Conduct provider-focused sessions for ELT to support API consumption.
Challenges:
- Coordinating multiple external integrations (AAMVA, courts, other state systems).
- Aligning sessions to appropriate stakeholder groups (state vs. lenders/service providers vs. dealers).
Planned Actions:
- Maintain dedicated teams for AAMVA integrations and in-state integrations.
- Conduct API onboarding sessions for ELT service providers.
Action Items for Topic 2:
- AAMVA Services Integration Plan
  - Description: Maintain/update integration plans for required interstate notifications (e.g., license revocations).
  - Responsible: AAMVA Integration Team
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Ensure compliance and timely notifications.
- In-State Court System Integration Mapping
  - Description: Document DUI data flows and apply to license records; ensure statutory compliance.
  - Responsible: In-State Integration Team
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Map triggers and processing steps end-to-end.
- ELT API Onboarding Sessions
  - Description: Conduct technical sessions for service providers on ELT API usage.
  - Responsible: ELT Product and Engineering Teams
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Provide API docs, sandbox access, and support contacts.
Open Questions for Topic 2:
- Which service providers are next in queue for ELT API onboarding?
- Are there specific statutory timelines for interstate notifications that affect integration SLAs?
## Topic 3: API V2 and Unified Data Model; Product Replatforming
- Tyler asked about API V2 robustness: “[Tyler] … the apis you guys are looking to v2 … make them more robust …”
- Kevin emphasized it’s broader than APIs: VTAS (Vehicle Titling and Registration) initially built for West Virginia was not easily portable. A Gen 2 is underway for Rhode Island and Kentucky:
  - “[Kevin] … Gen 2 version … deployed in … Rhode Island and Kentucky … much smaller set of features … than … West Virginia.”
  - Plan to retrofit West Virginia with Gen 2 and expand features.
- Unified data model referenced by Tyler and affirmed by Kevin:
  - “[Tyler] Hence the unified data model …”
  - “[Kevin] So.”
- Kevin noted high workload across states and phases, and interest from New Jersey and Illinois:
  - New Jersey: Phase 2 to include full vehicle titling, dealers submitting transfer agreements electronically.
  - Illinois: ELT in place; pursuing dealer submissions.
Decisions and Direction:
- Pursue an opinionated product approach minimizing per-state customization; standardize process and product akin to SAP model.
- Use state plugins to encapsulate state-specific logic/UI displays; engineering owns product, state implementations own plugins.
- Feedback loop from state plugin team to engineering to generalize features.
Challenges:
- Retrofitting rich feature set from West Virginia into standardized Gen 2 while supporting scalability.
- Coordinating dealer involvement and electronic submissions in states planning expansions.
- Managing workload across multiple concurrent state projects.
Planned Actions:
- Continue building Gen 2 VTAS for portability and scalability.
- Integrate dealer submission capabilities where states request (NJ, IL).
- Develop and iterate unified data model underpinning the products.
Action Items for Topic 3:
- VTAS Gen 2 Rollout Plan
  - Description: Define scope and deployment targets for Gen 2 VTAS in Rhode Island and Kentucky; plan retrofit for West Virginia.
  - Responsible: Engineering (Product) and State Implementation Team
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Account for feature parity gaps vs. West Virginia.
- Unified Data Model Definition
  - Description: Formalize unified data model supporting portability across states; align with API evolution.
  - Responsible: Data Architect (under Kevin), Enterprise Architects
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Ensure cross-product compatibility (VTAS, ELT, IDs).
- Dealer Electronic Submissions Enablement (NJ, IL)
  - Description: Design and implement workflows and integrations for dealers to submit transfer agreements electronically.
  - Responsible: State Implementation Team (NJ, IL), Engineering (Product)
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Consider UI, authentication, compliance requirements.
- State Plugin Governance
  - Description: Establish process for plugin feature feedback to be integrated back into core product when generally useful.
  - Responsible: State Implementation Team, Engineering
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Create criteria for generalization; maintain plugin registry.
Open Questions for Topic 3:
- What specific elements of the unified data model are prioritized first?
- What criteria determine when a state plugin feature should be promoted into the core product?
- What is the exact scope for NJ Phase 2 and IL dealer submissions beyond initial statements?
## Topic 4: Organizational Roles, Hiring, and Structure
- Tyler asked about attendance and roles for on-site/JAD sessions: “[Tyler] … is that something you typically are attending? Is that an Abby thing.”
- Kevin explained a spectrum from business to technical:
  - “[Kevin] … Abby as a business person … solution architect … enterprise architects … engineering.”
  - Currently hiring for the Solution Architect role; Kevin is still doing enterprise architect work with two other enterprise architects, plus a data team under him (may change), retaining a data architect.
- Leadership structure:
  - Abby: VP of Product.
  - Britt: VP of Engineering (product engineering). “[Kevin] … she just started this week.”
  - Ian: VP in charge of state implementations (services-like).
  - Bo: CTO, has historically attended sessions.
- Tyler and Kevin discussed avoiding excessive customization (contrast with OnBase):
  - “[Kevin] … actively trying to avoid … more the SAP model … integrate with everything … statutory requirements … product should be the same … state plugins …”
Decisions and Direction:
- Fill the Solution Architect role to bridge business and technical.
- Maintain clear ownership boundaries: State Implementation Team owns state plugins; Engineering owns product.
Challenges:
- Kevin’s bandwidth covering enterprise architecture plus data oversight.
- Scaling teams to support rapid growth and multiple simultaneous state efforts.
Planned Actions:
- Proceed with hiring Solution Architect.
- Clarify data team reporting and retain data architect under Kevin if team moves.
Action Items for Topic 4:
- Hire Solution Architect
  - Description: Recruit and onboard a Solution Architect to operate between business and technical teams for discovery and design.
  - Responsible: Kevin, HR/Recruiting
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Role participates in JAD/discovery and solution design.
- Define Data Team Structure
  - Description: Confirm organizational alignment for data engineers; maintain data architect under Kevin.
  - Responsible: Kevin, Leadership (Abby, Britt)
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Communicate changes to teams; ensure continuity.
- Session Attendance Protocol
  - Description: Establish who attends which sessions (Abby/business, Solution Architect, enterprise architects, engineering as needed).
  - Responsible: Abby, Kevin, Ian
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Document guidelines for different products and phases.
Open Questions for Topic 4:
- What is the timeline and candidate profile for the Solution Architect hire?
- Will data engineers move under another org, and when?
## Topic 5: VTAS V1, Headless Gen 2, and System-of-Record Awareness
- Tyler asked the status of V2/Vnext: “[Tyler] … how much of this V2 or Vnext is in place today.”
- Kevin detailed:
  - VTAS V1 was West Virginia-specific and not portable.
  - A slimmed Gen 2 exists, used headlessly where ELT needs title info; no UI, manages titles, aware of system-of-record status.
  - In Illinois, VTAS is not system of record; headless VTAS brokers calls to the state mainframe when needed: “[Kevin] … ELT knows how to talk to VITAS … go talk to the state and get it from their mainframe …”
  - Full system-of-record functionality for VTAS remains to be built when the product is the authoritative source.
- Tyler summarized: V1 in WV; V1.5 deployed alongside; V2 planned for scalable build. Kevin confirmed: “[Kevin] … that helps out a lot.”
Decisions and Direction:
- Continue using headless VTAS with system-of-record awareness; expand to full SOR capabilities where applicable.
- Build scalable V2 VTAS that can operate as SOR or integrate with external SORs.
Challenges:
- Designing robust SOR logic and integration pathways.
- Balancing minimal feature sets vs. necessary functionality for states.
Planned Actions:
- Implement full SOR features in VTAS for states where the product is authoritative.
- Maintain integration patterns for non-SOR states.
Action Items for Topic 5:
- System-of-Record Feature Design

  - Responsible: Engineering (VTAS), Enterprise Architects
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Include fallback and reconciliation with external systems.
- Non-SOR Integration Enhancements
  - Description: Strengthen VTAS integrations with state mainframes for non-SOR deployments (e.g., Illinois).
  - Responsible: VTAS Engineering, State Integration Team
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Ensure reliability, error handling, and performance.
Open Questions for Topic 5:
- Which upcoming states will designate VTAS as system of record vs. non-SOR?
- What auditing and compliance requirements apply to SOR operations?
## Topic 6: Growth, Office Space, and Logistics
- Organizational growth:
  - “[Kevin] … we are growing like crazy … moved in October … already … out of space.”
  - New VP of Engineering (Britt) started this week.
  - Expansion to the other side of the building; mention of a “secret door” leading to future client experience center.
  - Considering another floor: “[Tyler] … sarah pointed out another floor …”
- Work policy:
  - Four days a week in-office is policy, with flexibility for appointments and weather: “[Kevin] … policy … four days a week …”
- Personal notes:
  - Holidays and break timing; local references to Berea, Fat Head’s, and Puritas Nursery model train display.
- Next steps:
  - Tyler asked about follow-up: “[Tyler] … should i expect to hear from sarah …”
  - Kevin: “[Kevin] i would guess you would hear from sarah … i’ll let her know that we talked … give her my feedback.”
Decisions and Direction:
- Maintain growth trajectory and plan for space expansion; build client experience center.
- Follow-up with Sarah for recruiting/process next steps.
Challenges:
- Rapid team onboarding and space constraints (“who is that person?”).
- Scheduling across holidays.
Planned Actions:
- Kevin to inform Sarah of the meeting and provide feedback.
- Tyler to await contact from Sarah.
Action Items for Topic 6:
- Provide Meeting Feedback to Sarah
  - Description: Notify Sarah of the conversation and share Kevin’s feedback on Tyler’s fit.
  - Responsible: Kevin
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Affects next-step coordination.
- Coordinate Next Steps with Tyler
  - Description: Sarah to reach out to Tyler regarding process/hiring steps.
  - Responsible: Sarah
  - Time Frame: Not specified
  - Due Date: Not specified
  - Notes: Holiday schedules may affect timing.
Open Questions for Topic 6:
- When will Sarah contact Tyler given holiday schedules?
- What is the timeline for building out the client experience center behind the “secret door”?
## Additional Feedback and Alignment
- Tyler expressed strong fit and enthusiasm: “[Tyler] … opportunity … tremendous … very excited.”
- Kevin affirmed fit: “[Kevin] … I think you’re a really good fit for this …”
- Agreement on opinionated workflows to reduce complexity compared to highly customizable systems: “[Tyler] I really like your concept of being a little bit more opinionated …” “[Kevin] Yeah.”
Summary of the Meeting:
- The discussion covered discovery/JAD practices tailored for state implementations, focusing on resolving legacy constraints (e.g., unique title IDs) and capturing stakeholder dialogue for architects.
- Product strategy emphasized portability and standardization through a unified data model, state plugins, and minimizing customization, with active work on VTAS Gen 2 and ELT integrations, including dealer submissions for NJ and IL.
- Organizational structure and hiring needs were clarified, particularly the Solution Architect role between business (Abby) and technical (enterprise/engineering), alongside leadership roles (Britt, Ian, Bo).
- Operational updates highlighted rapid growth, office expansion, and logistics, with immediate next steps for Sarah to follow up with Tyler after Kevin shares feedback.
- Both parties aligned on the approach and expressed mutual confidence in fit and direction.

ABOUT THIS HANDBOOK/DISCLAIMER
We prepared this handbook to help employees find the answers to many questions that they may have
regarding their employment with Champ Titles, Inc. Please take the necessary time to read it.
We do not expect this handbook to answer all questions. Supervisors and Human Resources also serve as a
major source of information.
Neither this handbook nor any other verbal or written communication by a management representative is,
nor should it be considered to be, an agreement, contract of employment, express or implied, or a promise
of treatment in any particular manner in any given situation, nor does it confer any contractual rights
whatsoever. Champ Titles, Inc. adheres to the policy of employment at will, which permits the Company or
the employee to end the employment relationship at any time, for any reason, with or without cause or
notice.
No Company representative other than the President may modify at-will status and/or provide any special
arrangement concerning terms or conditions of employment in an individual case or generally and any such
modification must be in a signed writing.
Many matters covered by this handbook, such as benefit plan descriptions, are also described in separate
Company documents. These Company documents are always controlling over any statement made in this
handbook or by any member of management.
This handbook states only general Company guidelines. The Company may, at any time, in its sole discretion,
modify or vary from anything stated in this handbook, with or without notice, except for the rights of the
parties to end employment at will, which may only be modified by an express written agreement signed by
the employee and the President.
This handbook supersedes all prior handbooks.
